Title: How to prove the Fibonacci sum $\sum \limits_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F_n}{p^n} = \frac{p}{p^2-p-1}$
Content: We may be familiar that given the Fibonacci series $F_n = 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8,\dots$ then $0.0112358\dots\approx 1/89$ . In fact, $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F_n}{10^n} =\frac{0}{10^0}+\frac{1}{10^1}+\frac{1}{10^2}+\frac{2}{10^3}+\dots = \frac{10}{89}$$ How do we prove that more generally, for $p > 1$ then, $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F_n}{p^n} = \frac{p}{p^2-p-1}$$ The above simply was the case $p = 10$ . P.S. Similarly, given the tribonacci numbers $T_n$ , then, $$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{T_n}{10^n}  = \frac{100}{889}$$ See this related post .
AcceptedAnswer: You can use Binet's formula, $$F_n=\frac{\phi^n-(-\phi)^{-n}}{\sqrt 5}$$ along with the usual geometric series formula to prove your claim: $$\begin{align*}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{F_n}{p^n}&=\frac1{\sqrt 5}\left(\frac1{1-\phi/p}-\frac1{1+(p\phi)^{-1}}\right)\\&=\frac{p(\phi^2+1)/(\sqrt 5)}{(p-\phi)(p\phi +1)}\\&=\frac{p\phi}{\phi p^2-(\phi^2-1)p-\phi}\\&=\frac{p\phi}{\phi p^2-\phi p-\phi}\\&=\frac{p}{p^2-p-1}\end{align*}$$
